citation.article-title: Rubricoccus marinus gen. nov., sp. nov., of the family ‘Rhodothermaceae’, isolated from seawater
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Rubricoccus marinus sp. nov.
Rubricoccus marinus (ma.ri′nus. L. masc. adj. marinus of the sea, marine).
Exhibits the following properties in addition to those given in the genus description.
Grows at 5–37 °C (optimum 20–30 °C), but not at 45 °C, at pH 5–9 and with 1–5 % (w/v) NaCl.

Positive for esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8), lipase (C14), leucine arylamidase, valine arylamidase, cystine arylamidase, trypsin, α-chymotrypsin, acid phosphatase and naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase, but negative for alkaline phosphatase, N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, α-and β-galactosidases, α- and β-glucosidases, β-glucuronidase, α-mannosidase and α-fucosidase.
Produces acetoin, reduces nitrate to nitrogen and weakly hydrolyses gelatin.
Acid is produced from aesculin, 2-ketogluconate, turanose and arabinose.
The major cellular fatty acids are iso-C17 : 1ω9c, C17 : 1ω8c, iso-C17 : 0 and C16 : 0.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 68.9 mol%.
The type strain, SG-29T ( = NBRC 107124T = KCTC 23197T), was isolated from the western North Pacific Ocean near Japan.
